cell.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1904.

div.head: THE PASSAGE OF THE FLEET.
div.p: We offer our sincere congratulations to the Government on the complete success of the measures which it adopted during the recent passage of the 2nd division of the Baltic Fleet through the Suez Canal. The stories spread by sensation-mongers and bruited abroad by members of the Russian secret service, who presumably wanted to show something for the pay squandered on them, had undoubtedly obtained general credence in Russian naval and political circles. The squadron was manned by crews most of whom knew as little of nautical life as Mr. W. 8. Gilbert's sea-lord, its officers, if of some professional standing, had expressed at Tangiers and elsewhere the most lively, and as the event proved, the most needless apprehension of a Japanese attack. All the materials were at hånd for a repetition of the Dogger incident which might have been fraught with the most calamitous consequences to the whole world. The effective patrolling of the banks and waters of the canal; the promptness with which our somewhat embarrassing guests have been escorted through the ditch' without accident or incident, and the entire absence of any hitch in the dispositions made by the Government, deserve unstinted praise. That there was & certain element of comedy in proceedings which recalled the spectacle of an agitated family being escorted over the safest of crossings, is obvious enough, but comedy might have been followed by the most appalling tragedy in the narrow waters of the canal but for the precautions of which we applaud the successful issue.

There can only be one opinion amongst those who were officially connected with the precautionary and other arrangements connected with the fleet's visit—thankfulness that no untoward incident took place. It was out of the question to suppose that the Japanese, who have behaved throughout the war with an exemplary correctness never excelled by any other nation, would be parties to any dastardly outrage in neutral waters. Trouble was only looked for from the Russian fleet itself. Every credit is due to the Canal Company's staff, the Coast Guards, and police officials, for the excellent manner in which the arrangements were made and carried out ; but whether they were made for the purpose of protecting the fleet from a possible treacherous Japanese attack, or for the purpose of comforting the excited minds of the officers of the fleet, and 80 saving them from once more making themselves notorious, it would perhaps not be well to ask.

The satirical article reprinted from the Pall Mall Gazette in our issue of 24th inst. was not altogether uncalled for. It is a fact that the authorities actually stopped the firing of the morning and evening Ramadan guns, lest the distant report should throw the fleet into another wild panic. Many of the other precautions taken were equally ludicrous, but they cannot be said to have been uncalled for. The wonder is that any admiral would allow his fleet to be nursed and tended in a way calculated to excite the contempt and ridicule of all nations.

The general attack on Port Arthur is progressing. The results are unknown. Geno rals Nakamura and Saito, who were leading specially trained bodies of swordsmen, charged into the Russian forts and engaged in a hand-to hand sanguinary encounter. The results of the charge are unknown.
(Router.)
Skirmishing continues. The rivers are completely frozen.
(Havas.)

div.head: ENGLAND AND THE WAR. AIDING THE RUSSIANS.

div.p: The Japanese Legation positively denies the purchase of coals mentioned on the 23rd inst.

Reuter's Agency understands that the shipments of British coal for Russia and the supply of munitions from British firms have excited many painful feelings among the Japanese. It is pointed out that subjects of Japan's ally are materially assisting Russia.
Baron Sayematsu, interviewed on the subject, is of opinion that Great Britain ought to do something in order to prevent a continuance of this situation.
(Reuter.)

div.head: CONFISCATION OF SS. "CHELTENHAM." CONFIRMED BY SUPREME PRIZE COURT.

div.p: The Supreme Prize Court has confirmed the confiscation of the British steamer Cheltenham.
(Reuter.)

div.head: SEDITION IN RUSSIA RIOTS AT SEVASTOPOL.

div.p: Serious riots have occurred here amongst the sailors in barracks. The causes are somewhat obscure, but seditious proclamations were found in the men's effects. The sailors wrecked their own quarters, and also those of the officers belonging to other naval divisions, who refused to join them. The pickets fired upon the rioters, wounding many and evet: tually restoring order.

div.head: FRENCH EMBASSY AT VATICAN. CREDITS SUPPRESSED.
Paris, November 26.
div.p: The Chamber of Deputies has suppressed the credits for the embassy to the Vatican.
(Havas.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: After presiding at the Council of Ministers at Abdeen Palace on Saturday, the Khedive received Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy and the Orthodox Coptio Patriarch in a private audience.
This morning, his Highness went to Abdeen Palace and received the Marquis Salvago-Raggi and M. Gennadis, the Italian and Greek Diplomatic Agents.
The former presented to his Highness the Marquis Neli-Luchi de Sovogna, the new Italian Consul at Cairo, and the latter, M. Rika kis, attaché to the Greek Diplomatic Agency.
His Highness also received Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, Sheik Ahmed Pasha, and Mr. Fowler.
This afternoon his Highness will grant an audience to Michalla Pasha.
This evening his Highness will give an Iftar to the Princes of the Khedivial Family, the Ministers and Under-Secretaries of State, and to officials of the rank of Mirmiran.
"AU DE ROUGE.”

div.head: The 20th HUSSARS
div.p: were inspected this morning by the General Officer Commanding.

div.head: PARIAT Dogs.
div.p: Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Menshieh quarter of Alexandria this evening will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Royal Berks' Move.--
div.p: The advance party of the three companies R. Berks Regiment, which are proceeding to Cairo, will take over the barracks at Abbassich on Thursday next.

div.head: GAMBLING HELL RAID. --
div.p: The Alexandria police made a raid on a gambling hell in Tewfik Pasha-street last night and arrested the owner, the cards and money being seized and sent to the Attarin police station.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE -
div.p: Mr. Hart, of the Serum Institute, Abbassieh, has been appointed cattle plague inspector in the provinces of Fayoum and Beni Souef and the Fashn, Maghagha and Beni Mazar districts of Minieh, in place of Mr. Dray, who has resigned.

div.head: K. S.C. -
div.p: Owners are reminded that nominations for the Paddock Handicap, to be run at the second Winter Meeting on the 25th and 27th January, 1905, close on 'Thursday, December 1. Owners who require paddock stalls for the coming season should apply at once as the number is limited.

div.head: EXECUTION.—
div.p: The Bedouin, Aly Amir, who murdered his brother Ahmed Amir in the Assiout province on October 12, 1903, was executed on Saturday at the prison of the Native Court of Appeal, Cairo. The Commandant of Police and the Chief of the Native Parquet were present at the execution.

div.head: A MOST REMARKABLE EXAMPLE
div.p: of the way in which the Anglo-Egyptian officials encourage British trade is seen in recent contracts given out by the Finance Ministry for articles in common use in the various Departments of the Government. More than half the ink is supplied from Hungary, although British firms tendered for the entire supply. Up to this year the whole supply was in British bands.

div.head: THE SUDD.--
div.p: A paper by Mr. A. F. Brown, "Notes on the Sudd Formation of the Upper Nile," was read at the last meeting of the Linnean Society in abstract by Mr. C. H. Wright. The notes include the tract of country between Lake No and Shambe, a military post on the left bank, 266 miles from that lake. The author gave a list of the plants forming the mass of vegetation which, favored by the silt brought down by the White Nile, is helping to block the shallow channels.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Curzon of Kodleston, Viceroy of India, is a passenger for Bombay by the P. &0. S.S. Persia, due at Port Said to-morrow.

Among those dining at Shepheard's Restaurant yesterday we noticed Col. Younghusband and some friends, Mr. F. C. Grew and a party of 8, Baron von Richthofen and a party of 5, Lady Duffey and party, Mr. Gordon Bennett, Marquis and Marquise d'Albufera, Baron and Baronne Gourgaud, Baronne de Reuter, and party, Mr. Loir, Mr. and Mrs. von Falcione, Mr. von Salisch, Michalla Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. de Kerautem, Mr. and Mrs. van der Wyck, Count Diepholz, Baron von Wersede, etc.
Lady Palmer is returning to Egypt shortly.
Mr. E. Tillard, as engineer to the Prisons Department, will receive a salary of L.E. 420 per annum.
Drs. Stanislao Rocchi and Constantin Papadimitriou have been authorized to practise in Egypt.
Mr. Rodih has been transferred as engineer to the Ministry of Public Works.

The following is a list of the passengers who left for the Nile trip by the P. S. Nefertari on Friday :-Mr. R. D. Mann, Mr. Fox Strangeways, Mrs. Louisa and Miss Calthorp, Capt. and Mrs. Schneider, Oberst and Mrs. Isenbart, Mr. HansIsenbart, Miss Teschendorf, Dr. and Mrs. Vogler, M. and Mme. Nahas Bey, Miss Chance, Miss Dudgeon, Mr. E. M. and Mrs. Ashley, Mr. and Mrs. F. R. Ashley, Mr. Hunter Dunn, Miss Bruce, Miss Burnet, Mr. and Mrs. Lee, Rev. and Mrs. J. B. Bristow, Mr. J. Priolian, Mr. W. Vincent.

div.head:
MISLEADING ADVERTISEMENTS.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Dear Sir,--My attention has been called to an absurdly inserted advertisement appearing in a paper called L'Egypte (The Egyptian Morning News) under the heading "Ellerman Lines, Ltd.," (City and City and Hall Lines), which is entirely incorrect and misleading, the steamers named therein being the Ellerman liners between London and Liverpool and Alexandria, for which I am agent. I shall be obliged by your calling attention to this in your next issue, as the only paper I advertise in at present is the Egyptian Gazette.
Yours truly,
N. E. TAMVACO.
Alexandria, 26 November, 1904.

P.S.-L'Egypte has no authority from me or, I understand, from Messrs. Cory Brothers & Co., Ltd., the Port Said agents of the 'City' Line, to publish advertisements respecting our respective companies, N. E. T.

div.head: THE BUDGET FOR 1905. THE ESTIMATES.
div.p: The following are the budgetary estimates for 1905 :
Expenditure: Ordinary expenditure L.E. 11,308,000
Special expenditure, 447,000
The estimates of revenue do not include the LE. 216,000 taken from the General Reserve Fund for the relief of taxation.

The land transfer dues have been reduced to 2%, which has brought about a decrease in revenue of L.E.250,000. A diminution in receipts of L.E.16,000 is also provided for owing to the suppression of the boat dues. On the other hand, there figures in the Estimates a sum of L.E.135,000, being the product of the sales of Free State property.

The estimates of expenditure do not include the sum of L.E.265,000, representing the economies resulting from the conversion of the Privileged Debt, which have hitherto been paid into the Fonds des Economies de la Conversion.
The actual increase in the expenditure amounts to L.E. 604,000, the greater portion of which figures in the Budget of Public Works, Railways, and Public Instruction.
A sum of L.E. 447,000 has been set aside for the special expenditure of the year, which up to now had been taken from the Reserve Fund.

div.head: RAILWAY COMMISSION.
div.p: We hear on good authority that the construction of the line from Salhieh to Kantara has been approved in principle, though work is not likely to be begun there till the Railway Commission has presented its report.

The members of the Commission left for Upper Egypt on Saturday. They inspected the Payoum line and stations and spent the night at Seilah station. Yesterday they inspected the line and stations between Wasta and Melawi.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers, which was held at Abdeen Palace on Saturday, gave its approval to the budgetary estimates for the coming year and to the Note of the Financial Adviser thereon. The fusion of the Helouan and Delta railways, the creation of a Sudan Irrigation Service, and the nomination of Messrs. Mitchell Innes and Rooca Serra to the Committee of Egyptian Antiquities also received the approbation of the Council.

div.head: IRRIGATION WORKS.
div.p: By Khedivial decree the Moudirs of Gharbieh, Galioubieh, Dakahlieh, Keneh, and Assouan are commanded to convoke the provincial councils of their respective Moudiriehs to examine the local irrigation works proposed for 1905. In place of the chief engineers of the Moudiriehs the Inspectors of Irrigation may be present, with & voice in the deliberations of the councils.
The dates of these meetings are as follows: Galioubieb, Deo. 3; Gbarbieh, Deo.4, Dakahlieh, Dec. 5; Keneh, Dec. 24 ; Assouan, Dec. 27.

div.head: BRASSERIES DES PYRAMIDES.
div.p: No less than 49,000 shares were applied for, but as the new issue only consisted of 5,000 shares, the share-holders of the company, who had the right of preference, were allotted 4,550 shares, while the outside public received one per cent.

div.head: THE HOUSING SCHEME.
div.p: Mr. Geo. B. Alderson writes : - My scheme is not based on any plea of poverty nor want of work for artisans. The foundation of the whole idea is due to the utter want of accommodation Jin Alexandria for artisans. In consequence of this dearth of suitable houses, good, honest and industrious workmen have to live in "Tat holes." without water laid on, because the landlords fear that their houses would collapse if the water pipes leaked. The "rat holes" are never repaired because the landlords assert that they are not worth repairing. In many cases even these dwellings have only holes in the top of the walls for light. Their sanitary condition is deplorable. My demand for gas is confined to the corridors alone. The project of remitting the 2 % tenants tax on these sınall tenements, averaging £1 per month rent, is based on the enormous expense of collecting these taxes in such cases. The scheme is worked out on a commercial basis and would provide a sure and profitable savings bank for the artisan, I ask for land sufficient to build seven such blocks, which would accommodate, roughly, say 1,000 families, possibly more, as many would be subdivided. If it is too much to ask for the grant of the land, then I would ask for & perpetual lease at a peppercorn rent. If they ask us to purchase, then to raise the capital becomes a speculation, and I fear in the end we should be in the same plight again as we are now. If the above scheme is not feasible, how is this urgent want to be provided for

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh. Fint Olses Botel. Newly builo. Era breezes. Dry Air. Near tram station, the promenado, and Mustapbs Pashs Barracks, Garden, Lawn Tennis. Good cuisine Modern to charges. Open all the year round. O. AQUILINA, proprietor. (Late of Thos. Cook & Sop): also General Manager, Tewók Palace Hotel Holonan.

div.head: CANEA OUTRAGES. TERRIBLE SCENES. A SIGNIFICANT CONFESSION. "OFFICERS ALL DRUNK.” CORRESPONDENTS EXPERIENCES.
div.p: Mr. Reginald Wyon, the Correspondent of the Daily Mail at Vienna, arrived at Alexandrie on Saturday evening by the Russian steamer Emperor Nicholas II., from Crete, and is staying at the Khedivial Hotel. He was at Canea during the time the Russian Fleet was there and gives a terrible account of the outrages committed by the officers and men.

During the thirteen days he stayed at Canea the streets were quite unsafe. Any woman found in the streets was pursued and treated with great rudeness, if the miscreants happened to catch her. The bars were looted and the restaurants were wrecked. Officers and men I were often "roaring" drunk at 9 a.m., and many of them lay in a helpless state of intoxication all about the quay and streets. The Cretans characterized them as absolute barbarians. Both officers and men spent any amount of money at Canea and at night the scenes baffled description. All the sailors used to come ashore, while many lived on shore and overstayed their leave with impunity. When evening came on bands of them used to raid the streets and the fighting amongst themselves was of a ferocious description. In one night alone three Russians were killed by their fellows in a most brutal manner, for they were jumped upon as they lay prostrate until their skulls were completely smashed in!

A significant confession, Mr. Wyon informed us, was made by many of the officers and men I while at Canea. They declared that they were all drink on the night of the incident on the Dogger Bank. They all expressed a bitter hate | of England. Mr. Wyon was himself attacked by drunken sailors while riding in the country in the presence of some officers, who did not take the slightest notice. His immunity from serious maltreatment during his stay at Canea was due to the fact that he pretended to be a German, as no Englishman's life would have been secure at the hands of these ruffians. All the sailors expressed open contempt of the capacity of their officers.

The following incident is sufficient to show I the discipline prevailing. Two officers of I different ranks had a dispute on board a destroyer. They quarreled in front of the crew and the inferior officer drew a revolver on his superior. The latter jumped into the sea to save his life, but as he could not swim he was nearly drowned. He was picked up and got ashore, where he stayed for three days, during which time he was always drunk. On the fourth day he came aboard and made it up with the other officers. This destroyer is now lat Piraeus. She ran down & Greek vessel after leaving Crete, and damaged herself so considerably that she had to go into dock at Piraeus.
Mr. Wyon speaks some Slav and he interviewed a number of the men. He was struck by the great respect with which they spoke of the Japanese
A number of colliers are still at Souda Bay Awaiting the arrival of more Russian vessels.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. DEPARTURE FROM SUEZ. SHIPS COAL IN BAY.
div.p: The Baltic Fleet sailed this morning escorted by the Coast Guard cruisers Abbas and Nourel-Bahr up to Sadwan in order to carry out Egypt's neutrality. Yesterday the warships and destroyers coaled from transports in the bay
The British yacht Emerald has just obtained a permit for her departure. Her destination is undeclared.
It is stated that the Canal dues for the fleet amounted to 370,000 fra.
Mr. Maximoff, the Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, returned to Cairo El from Port Said on Saturday morning.

div.head: TRANSPORTS AT PORT SAID.
div.p: H. M. transport Assaye (Capt. E. K. Dowell, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said on Saturday afternoon, outward bound for Bombay. The troops on board, including women and children, numbered 1,489 of all ranks. Col. W. H. Murray, 1st Battalion Royal Scots, was the officer commanding.
The homeward bound transport Sicilia was due at Port Said early this morning.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD,
div.p: ALEXANDRIA. 8a. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandra. Facing the road Central position. Under English management 173.11-901

div.head: CONDITION OF HELOUAN. PETITION OF INHABITANTS.
div.p: The following is the text of a petition submitted by the inhabitants of Helouan Town to the Earl of Cromer, the Minister of Public Works, the Minister of Finance, and the Minister of the Interior:
"The undersigned, owners of property in, and residents of Helouan, beg to submit on behalf of themselves, other inhabitants and visitors to the town of Helouan the following:-!

1. They invite the attention of the Govern- ! ment to the many previous complaints they have made with regard to the unsatisfactory working of the Cairo-Helouan Railway Co., and they request the authorities to take the oppor. tunity of the transfer of the concession of the Helouan Railway Co. to the Delta Light Railway Company to safeguard the interests of Helouan and its inhabitants in promoting a thoroughly efficient service.

2. They draw the attention of the authorities to the present condition of the streets and roads both as regards cleanliness, lighting and repair, to the unfiltered and therefore dirty condition of the water supplied to the houses for drinking and other purposes, and they also feel very considerably the absence of any road for vehicular traffic between Cairo and Helouan. There are also several matters of less importance, such as the embellishment of the town, the providing of public attractions, and the planting of trees along the streets, which they think should be taken in hand.

3. Since the crying needs of the town are so great they think it a great hardship that money derived from the local taxation should be allocated to objects in which they have no concern-for instance, the amount paid by the town of Helouan last year in house-tax, water and other rates amounted to about £6,000, of which sum only about £1,750 was allotted to the town of Helouan.
4. They also object to the constitution of the present Local Commission :
Firstly, inasmuch as its members have no real power in promoting the interests of the town.

Secondly, the unworkable character of the Commission, the official members not being responsible to the Commission as a body but to the heads of the departments of which they happen to be the nominees. They therefore humbly request the conversion of the Local Commission into a genuine responsible "Municipality," or that the administration of the town be placed in charge of a Government Department, as it was before the creation of the Local Commission.

5. Owing to the urgency of these grievances your petitioners beg and pray that there petition be considered at an early date so that it | possibly the financial part may be rectified in this year's coming Budget.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The next meeting of the Municipal Commission will take place on Wednesday, the 30th inst. at 9 p.m. The following is the official programme of the proceedings -
1. Communications diverses (lettre ministé. rielle relative au nouveau réglement sur les pharmaciens).
2. Rapport du Comité spécial, au sujet du collecteur-Est.
3. Administrateur délégué auprès de lal! Compagnie des Baux. 4. Demandes de crédits :
1) pour la construction de chambres au-dessus de la nouvelle aile de la Bibliothèque.
2) pour aménagements à faire au fort Kamarieh, en vue de la rage.
3) pour gratifications aux percepteurs.
4) pour la souscription à un dictionnaire français-arabe.
5) pour affaires judiciaires. Virement de crédit.
5. Question relative à la construction de maisons à bon marché.
6. Question relative à la Commission des travaux d'entretien des quais et à la durée de la période d'entretien des travaux.
7. Demande d'organisation d'un service de camions automobiles par Mr. Théodoridis.
8. Question relative à la tour dite des Romains.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: The final performance of the Italian opera company which has been performing at this theater for the past month was given last night, Il Trovatore being staged, while Mignon was given in the afternoon, before a large and delighted audience. It goes without saying that with such artists as Signa. Monti-Baldini and Sig. Tomasini, the representation of the opera was excellent. Carmen was given on the previous evening, when Signa. Monti-Baldini gave of her best. JA better Carmen than that presented by this charming artiste it would be impossible to find. Signa Monti-Baldini throws her whole soul into the character and invests it with a degree of interest which we have found lacking in most other exponents.
The company leaves for Cairo to-day and will open at the Verdi Theatre, probably on Wednesday, with Aida.
ZIZINIA THEATRE.

M. de Tisci Rubini, the celebrated bass, will take the role of King Mark in Tristan et Iseult at the Zizinis Theater this evening, on the occasion of the opening performance of the Italian opera company,

div.head: SINKING OF BRITISH PINNACE.
div.p: H. M. S. Sealark left here on the 7th inat. for survey work and returned yesterday. Dur. ng surveying operations the vessel encountered heavy weather, which caused the loss of her steam pinnace. The latter was being loved by the Sealark while they were making for some landmarks. A heavy ses swept over the pinnace and caused it to sink. She then burned over and in doing so the tow ropes broke. She sank in about 40 fathoms of water. No explosion of the boiler occurred and ill hands were saved.

A football match takes place this afternoon between H.M.8. Sealark and "Suakin." The local team stands a good chance of winning as they have had a good deal of practice lately and have some excellent players, including Kaimakam Drury Bey.

The Khedivial mail steamer arrived here from Suez on the 17th and brought about 74 passengers for Suakin. Amongst them were Mr. and Mrs. Gaiger, the former English secretary to the Director, Sudan Railways, Suakin, and Mr. Maylor, the engineer sent out to erect the condensers for the Suakin Railway. Mr. Bailey, head foreman of works, Suakin, had charge of the temporary erection of the two condenser boilers, and Mr. Maylor will erect the remainder.

Bimbashi P. C. Lord, R.E., Acting Chief Engineer, Buskin Railway, has been confined to his house for the last fortnight through illness, but is now feeling better, and it is hoped that in a few days he will be able to resume his duties.

The telephone exchange is now complete between Suakin and Graham's Point, and all the offices at both ends can now communicate with each other. Telephone communication is also being pushed forward on the railway line, under the supervision of Corporal George, R.E. They have reached Handoub already and in a day or two will be at Railhead, so that Suakin, Graham's Point, and Railhead will be in communication.
Colonel Macauley Bey, Director, Sudan Rail. ways, is expected here by the next steamer from Suez.
It is rumored that H.E. Sirdar is likely to pay a visit here in March.

The S.S. Mahallah, which arrived here on the 17th inst., brought an engineer and several workmen with implements and tools for the digging of wells at Sheikh Barghout, which of course is to be the new Sudan port.

Mr. Achille-Kredi, the sub-contractor of the new Alexandria quays, arrived by the same steamer in order to study the place. He will probably obtain contracts for dredging the barbour, constructing quays, eto. He returned to Suez to-day by the S.S. Rahmanieh.
The S.S. Calioubieh arrived here from Suez yesterday with stores for the Suakin-Atbara Railway and machinery for well-sinking at Sheikh Barghout

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
div.p: Règlement sur les constructions
Dispositions Sanitaires Le Dr. Gotec Lioh vient de communiquer au chef de l'Administration ses observations, à propos du règlement et les constructions.
Voici comment il présente son projet de dispositions sanitaires :
Je me permets de vous exposer encore plus particulièrement la considération qui a motivé la rédaction de certains articles du présent projet du règlement.

Le titre À prévoit une réglementation diverse pour différentes parties de la ville et banlieue. Pareille réglementation par zones est adoptée presque dans toutes les grandes cités de l'Europe; elle est nécessitée par les différences de la condition Boisle et hygiénique de la population aux différents quartiers et faubourgs. Vu ces conditions différentes, il est matériellement impossible d'assurer le même progrès . giénique à tous les quartiers indistinctes. ment; certaines prescriptions hygiéniques d'ordre élémentaire pourront et devront être imposées pour toute la ville, même por les quartiers les plus publics et les plus pauvres (voir tires B, C, D de o présent projet de Règlement); d'autres prescriptions, d'ordre supérieur, et qui supposent déjà un certain degré de bien être des habitants ne pourront être exigées que pour les quartiers situés de la ville et spécialement pour les villégiatures de Ramleh, Moharrem Bey et du Quartier: Greo. Les dispositions spéciales sont dans l'intérêt même des habitants de ces quartiers. tiers Aires; car elles visent à la conservation de l'état actuel de ces quartiers, en tant qu'ils correspondent aux exigences de l'hygiène et de l'esthétique, et par contre à la disparition de toutes les défectuosités mutuelles de ces quartiers. Je me permets de citer à l'appui de ma thèse deux exemples de notre ville même.

Le quartier Grec souffre beaucoup par le voisinage immédiat des misérables échecs de Bab Charki, tant au point de vue de la propreté des rues que partout au point de vue de danger de propagation de maladies infectieuses ; après l'adoption du présent projet de Règlement, lequel De toldre pas de pareilles constructions dans les quartiers appartenant à la première zone, aucune de ces échecs ne pourra être ni nouvellement construite ni réparée, et elles tendront vite à disparaître. Un second exemple très instructif se présente

Ramleh ; dans ce quartier qui devrait rester réservé exclusivement à la villégia. Mais on commence déjà à ériger de vraies casernes de maison, ainsi que des tas de baraques malpropres; tout cela ne pourrait pas continuer et devrait disparaître de nouveau après l'adoption de notre présent projet de Règlement.

En ce qui concerne la délimitation des trois zones proposées sur le plan de notre ville, je me suis limité à donner dans l'art 3 du présent projet un premier essai de cette délimitation, tout en me tenant, le plus possible, aux conditions schnelles des quartiers respectifs. La délimitation du défi. Une initiative pourra être faite plus tard par un Comité spécial, après l'adoption du principe.
En ce qui concerne les titres B, C, D du présent projet, j'ai peu de chose à ajouter.

Les arts. 4, 6, 7, 8, 16, 18, 19, 20 tendent à assurer de la lumière et de l'air à toutes les parties de la maison. L'art. 5 tend à faire paraître les cours excessivement étroits et malpropres comme elles existent actuellement dans tant de maisons, et qui boit même un danger direct en cas d'incendie.
Les arts. 9 et 10 visent la protection contre les rats, reconnus comme propagateurs principaux de la peste.
Les arts. 11, 12, 13 se dirigent contre l'humidité eto. eto.

L'art. 26 mérite une explication spéciale; en effet, il est impossible de demander que dans les quartiers où il n'existe pas d'égout public, les eaux ménagères, eaux de bains eto. soient traitées de la même façon que les matières excrémentielles ; au point de vue hygiénique il est d'ailleurs parfaitement admissible de faire écouler des eaux sous certaines conditions bien entendu
dans des païta à fond perdu.

Es dernier lied je me permets de faire observer que l'adoption du présent projetde règlement ne sera que le premier pas pour arriver au but proposé. Il faudrait voter plus tard une loi sanitaire générale pour notre ville, applicable tant aux maisons existantes qu'aux nouvelles contractions.

Cette loi sanitaire produirait les résultats | les plus heureux même si elle ne s'étendait qu'aux prescriptions les plus élémentaires, surtout en ce qui concerne l'alimentation d'eau potable et l'enlèvement des matières résiduels - prescriptions essentielles qui pourtant à l'heure actuelle sont encore absolument négligées dans la plupart des habitations de notre ville.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: ( Aujourd'hui à midi et demi )
Ainsi que nous l'avions prévu, la baisse de ces derniers jours n'a pas continué longtemps. Il y a eu ce matin une reprise générale.
La Banque Nationale, qui avait débuté à 23 5/8, a décroché en clôture le prix de 23 13/16 acheteurs.
Il en est de même pour la Delta Light. Faible à l'ouverture à 14 9/16, elle remonte graduellement jusqu'à 14 3/4 acheteurs.
D'autre part la Salt, qui avait ouvert à 39 tombe en clôture à 38/6. | Sont également en reprise la Filature à 15/16,
la Crown Brewery à 220, les Markets à 26, la | Nungovich à 9 3/8 vendeurs.
Les Cotton Mills passent de 8/6 vendeurs à 8/6 acheteurs. On vend à 8/9.
Par contre on fléchit sur l'Anglo-American Nile à 5 3/16, sur les Eaux du Caire à 1120 et sur la Ramleh Railway à 8 5/16.

div.head: HELOUAN'S SANATORIUM. "AL HAYAT."
div.p: To residents of Egypt in search of quiet and fresh air, Helouan is well known. Visitors come in increasing numbers every year to enjoy the dry, keen air of the waste and to find a new Biskra at the edge of the Arabian desert, and we have only to look down on Helouan from the neighboring hills to realize the steady growth of the town. New villas, pensions, and hotels are springing up everywhere, but there is ample room for expansion, and it will be & long day before Helouan becomes overcrowded.

Of the new establishments that have sprung up in the last two years "Al Hayat '' is indisputably the finest, combining, as it does, the most modern sanitary and architectural improvements with every advantage in the way of situation. Founded with the intention of affording invalids and persons in need of quiet a comfortable abode fitted up with all the appliances known to modern hygienic knowledge, Al Hayat was first opened last Christmas. Built upon limestone rock, it lies about 290 feet above the level of the Nile and about 5 minutes' walk east of the Helouan Railway Station and W.E. of the Bathing Establishment. The entrance of the main building faces North looking towards the Observatory, while away to the West lies the town, from which the Sanatorium is absolutely separated, a good 150 yards dividing it from the nearest houses. As the whole building stands within its own grounds, which have an area of 40,000 square meters, there is no danger of its ever suffering from the extension of the town, of which it is quite independent.
Taking the lift from the entrance to the 4th floor a passage leads to the dining hall, which forms the middle block of the building.

The ground floor of Al Hayat contains the servants' quarters and the 1st floor is reserved for the management, manager's quarters, offices, medical reception-rooms, doctor's rooms, medico-'' mechanical appliances, and baths of all sorts electric, vapor, sand and galvano-faradic—for the treatment of invalids ordered to carry out a "cure.” The water for the bath-rooms is supplied by the Helouan Water Company and passes through a large Howatson sand filter, while for drinking purposes it is filtered a second time by the Berkefeld process.

On the 2nd, 3rd and 4th floors, all of which are served by a lift, are the bed-rooms, eighty in number, with private sitting-rooms for visitors. Nearly all face due South, looking into the inner court and garden of the hotel, round the N. side of which, and also facing South, run the open "Liegehallen"and verandahs, comfortably furnished with "Liegestuhls” and chairs and screened from the desert wind (sometimes too keen even at Helouan) by the dining hall and the buttress of rock on which the pavilion stands. In this open space invalids can enjoy to the full a clear view westward commanding the town of Helouan, the Nile, and the whole field of Pyramids from Mena House to Bedrashein without being in the least troubled by glare or wind. Smuts are unknown, thanks to the employment of four smoke consumers, and at night the garden is lit up by electric arc lamps.

There is room here for over 100 persons, but the problem of ventilation has not been neglected and air and light are secured by 27 windows which give fine views on all but the north side. The floor of the dining hall is-parquet, a balcony can accommodate at least 20 musicians, and prompt table service is guaranteed by the system of lifts communicating with the kitchens on the ground floor. Needless to say, there is an enormous storage room below, and the number of ice-chests and cupboards is sufficient for every emergency.

There is room here for over 100 persons, but the problem of ventilation has not been neglected and air and light are secured by 27 windows which give fine views on all but the north side. The floor of the dining hall is-parquet, a balcony can accommodate at least 20 musicians, and prompt table service is guaranteed by the system of lifts communicating with the kitchens on the ground floor. Needless to say, there is an enormous storage room below, and the number of ice-chests and cupboards is sufficient for every emergency.

From the dining-room a glass corridor leads to the south gallery adjoining the billiard saloon and thence through another glass walled passage one reaches the pavilion, which is without question the most attractive feature of the establishment, and which contains the hall, a card and smoking-room, music-room, reading-room, library, lavatories, etc. All round the southern and western face of the pavilion, and on the south side of the gallery and corridors, runs a terraced verandah giving a fine view of the Arabian desert towards Wadi Guerawi and Wadi el-Rachid and connected by a path with the southern garden descending in a series of terraces to the tennis court, croquet-grounds, shooting-gallery, and gazelle pens. Within 30 yards of the asphalt tennis court, but separated and quite hidden by a rocky spur, is a large hollow amphi. theater destined for sun-baths similar to those BO largely resorted to at Bad Veldes in Camithea. This, again, is absolutely screened from the desert wind, while it is a matter of a few seconds only to step out of the hotel grounds on to the desert plateau, where interesting walks with fine desert scenery and splendid air can be taken in half-a-dozen different directions.

To the east of the main building are a series of outbuildings, containing wine cellars, laundry, and ironing-rooms, and a building quite separate from the main body of the hotel for the reception of cases of infectious or suspicious diseases should any unhappily occur. In this little hospital pavilion are 5 bedrooms built round a central court and admirably lighted and ventilated, with a nurse's room connected with the sickrooms by electric bells and a large disinfecting stove of the latest model for linen. It has been thought advisable to keep the stables, with the numerous riding horses and donkeys, sand carts, etc., at a little distance from the hotel. An omnibus meets every train, and as far as postal arrangements go the hotel is as well served as any in Helouan.

Owing to the lamented death of the late Prof. E. Plehn, the post of medical director of Al Hayat has fallen to Dr. O. A. Wieck, who is supported by an assistant doctor, two nurses, and an analyst. Mr. Rudolf Springer, the energetic manager of Al Hayat, was, as our readers know, till recently the successful director of the Nungovich Hotels at Helouan. The extraordinary neatness and cleanliness of Al Hayat, with its fine situation, make it, in our opinion, an ideal Sanatorium, though the name must not be taken to imply that visitors are all subject, as at Davos or St. Moritz, to a severe and strict medical regime.

div.head: DOAN'S BACKACHE KIDNEY PILLS.
div.p: CURE ALL FORMS OF KIDNEY AND
BLADDER DISORDER.
Have you ever considered what neglecting your kidneys means?
Have you ever realised the terrible risk you are taking ?
Do you not pass in the streets, every day, men and women whose countenances show that their kidney trouble is gone too far, and they are beyond hope ?
How do you know them ?

By their pale, sallow, sunken, or bloated countenances; by their dull, lack-lustre eyes ; by their puffy or dark circles under the eyes ; by their slow languid movements, blotched, pimpled, and unhealthy complexions, and general appearance of weakness and debility.
In addition to their outward appearance, how do they feel themselves ?

Weak, worn out, tired and restless, nervous, irritable, and easily worried over the merest trifles, feverish and chilly, short of breath, dizzy, rheumatic, and they suffer from pains in the back, irregular heart, neuralgia, sleep| lessness, and are thoroughly run down.
Weak and unhealthy kidneys cause all these symptoms and many more.
Your kidneys are the most important organs of the body. Take care of them.

div.head: THE SWAMI RAMA.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir, -With reference to the article in your columns regarding the visit of the Swami Rama to Cairo, will you permit me, as a member of the British Indian community, to point out an error which appears therein ? "Swami Raina Tirtha,” during his stay in Egypt from the 10th to the 24th of the present month, was a guest of Mr. D. Chellaram at| Cairo and Port Said, and not of Mr. and Mrs. Plunkett, of the "De Rouge,” though the Swami frequently called upon Mr. and Mrs. Plunkett. I mention this fact only with the idea of pointing out to the readers of your paper that we, Hindus, were too proud of the honor done to us by the visit of this dignitary of our religion to permit it to be said that we did not welcome him in a practical way, viz., by opening the doors of our homes to him.

The principal point that the Swami indicated in his addresses was that it was the duty of Hindus to close their shops once a week, for preference on Sunday, as most convenient ; with reference to your statement as to his advising us to abstain from quarreling with our Moslem neighbors, as this has rarely or never occurred, the Swami did not find it necessary to mention this ; he, however, advocated the formation of a Hindu religious society, as being likely to be beneficial to our community.
Hoping that you will find space in your columns for this letter,
I am, etc.,

div.head: JUDGES AND THE VERNACULAR.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir -- Your endorsement of the Judicial Adviser's scheme of instituting an examination in Arabic for the English judges and other officials of the Ministry of Justice, will be received with general applause except by those favored a few who, secure in their billets on the Bench of the Native Courts, have hitherto neglected to make themselves proficient in the language in which the cases they are supposed to decide upon are pleaded. I am no lawyer, but it has twice fallen to my lot to serve on a jury in Egypt where Arabic-speaking witnesses have been obliged to give their evidence in the Consular Court through the medium of an interpreter. I have on each occasion been impressed by the unfairness of such a system. The witnesses, who were natives of the lower classes, were often obviously incapable of grasping the significance of cross-examination. The questions of the lawyers, transmitted through the medium of an interpreter, who spoke excellent Arabic, were often more or less unintelligible to the witnesses, cognisant only of the ordinary Egyptian patois. The results were unfair both to the judge, jury, lawyers, and witnesses, and a most erroneous impression was produced on the Court. But in these cases only part of the evidence was given in Arabic. For an English judge in the Native Courts to have to try an entire case conducted in a language which he cannot follow is a far more impossible task, and for my part I would far rather have an English inspector of the Ministry of the Interior or an officer of the police, who is well acquainted with Arabic, to try a case in which I was a party, than to have a capable judge who did not know the language. It is a shameful scandal that there should be any English judge in the Native Courts unable to follow cases closely in Arabic, and it says very little for the efficiency of the Ministry of Justice that such men should be allowed to occupy their posts. There are, of course, some English judges in the Native Courts who are excellent Arabic scholars, but the fact that there are some exceptions is a slur on the Ministry, and the sooner it is remedied the better. It must afford good grounds for contempt on the part of the Native Bar to see such gentlemen remain year after year as judges and to observe that they make no attempt to become more proficient.
I am, etc.,

div.head: STREET NOMENCLATURE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Dear Sir,-

In your article on "Street Nomenclature" in yesterday's issue, you are really too severe on the hard-working, fast driving Public Works Dept. of Cairo. You are really, Sir, too much "down" on this noble department, and do not give them credit for what they really do. For instance, there is a street, not 200 yards long, which they have named "Haret-el-Madrastein” no less than eleven times, where twice would have been sufficient. Just fancy, Mr. Editor, the trouble and labor of putting up eleven names in one street ! You should really give them credit for this wonderful performance, and you really cannot but expect that some streets will be yet unnamed, if they are all to be named eleven times. But there is another side to the question. These name-plates cost at least 2 francs each. Therefore, 9 surplus plates in one street means 18 francs of the tax-paye s' money actually thrown in the street, besides the cost of labor in putting them up. What more would you ask, Sir, than having a class of officials in the P. W. Dept. Who knows how to spend the money ?
I am, etc.,
